p.s: In the following it will be analyzed how the formal and poetic devices intensify Shakespear'sShakespeare's view.
Sonnet 138 follows its strict demands of Shakespearean sonnets.
It is devideddivided into three quatrains, which introduce the argument and the Volta and the couplet, which consists of the main meaning and the conclusion.
The rhythm contains a abab cdcd efef gg rhyme scheme.
The metrical pattern is aan iambic pentameter in which aan unstressed syllable is followed by a stressed one.
This form is a sound of a heartbeat which makes the sonnet very emotional, alive and meant to be presented.
The Volta in line 9 But wherefore says she not she is unjust? explains the turning point and guides the sonnet into another direction.
In order to introduce the theme of the sonnet the author chooses to announce the adressedaddressed person with [...] my love [...] (l. 1).
It represents the theme directly and the reader knows that the sonnet is about a loving and carrying relationship.
The enjambment from line 1 till 2 to also consists of an antithesis.
The speaker claims that he/she belivesbelieves her/him by telling the truth but also knows that the adresseaddressee is lying (l. 2).
It illustrates that the speaker wants to believe his/her love (l. 1) but also knows that it is realistic to acknowledge the fact that he/she is aging.
The reader can easily relate to this situation because he/she can understand the struggle of the speaker is in and therefore, feels also trapped.
Moreover, the reader knows that the speaker's love (l. 1) is a woman because he/she adressesaddresses her with she (l. 1) and her (l. 2).

The comparison in line three [...] think me some untutor'd youth, [...] underlines how the speaker is worried that he/she is not enough for her because he/she has not lived his young days to the fullest.
The speakers feels inexperienced and helpless.
The reader is curriouscurious and wants to know if this accusation is true in the ees of the adresseaddressee.
Furthermore, the speaker goes on overthinking about how he/she believes that that his/her love thinks that he/she has outlived his best days and is not so young anymore (l. 5, 6).
It represents the insecurities the speaker has and illustrate that he/she claims that the love their have mmight not be enough despite their problems.
Moreover, the metaphor [...] false speaking tongue [...] (l. 7) underlines the image more clearly and shows how the adresseaddressee is lying directly to the speaker's face.
He/she is thereby very astonished.
The reader is also shocked by this act and is interested how this behaviour can be tolerated.
Besidesmore, the speaker continues by explaining that [...] both sides [...] (l. 8) are surpressingsupressing the obvious truth of aging.
The Volta in line 9 is being introduced through a rethoricalrhetorical question.
It expresses how the reader does not understand why his/her love does not justify that she is wrong.
The speaker continues with another rethoricalrhetorical question in which he/she also judges him/herself of not telling the truth of being old (l. 10).
This stresses the turning point in the sonnet directly.
At first the speaker explains how both parties lie to one another for not hurting each otherseach other's feelings.
But through the rethoricalrhetorical questions the speaker finally starts to question their behaviour and almost comes to a conclusion.
Therefore, this speaker has the readersreader's full attention because the reader starts asking him/herself why this action is pushed through.
In addition the personification [...] love's best habit [...] (l. 11) identifysidentifies love (l. 11) as a person with having characteristics and habits.
It underlines that love's best character trait is trust.
The speaker astablishedestablished this but weaken'sweakens this argument by justifying it with the metaphor [...] age in love loves not to have years told [...] (l. 12).
It expresses that even though the foundation of a relationship is trust one should never compare love with age because love cannot be described in years.
It is inevitable.
The reader can relate to the thoughts of the speaker.
He/she claims that when in matters of love, lying can also be tolerated if it happens on a trust worthy and carrying base.
Also the reader is being remaindedreminded of the boundless power of love.
Lastly, the couplet concludes how the speaker will continue loving their relationship even with their flaws (ll. 13-14).
The reader feels the warmth and comfort in these lines and enjoys the happy ending of the sonnet.
